text:
In this video, you’ll see how you can 
simplify software-as-a-service (SaaS)

risk assessment with AWS 
Marketplace Vendor Insights.

From a unified dashboard, you can 
view vendors’ security and compliance

information and evaluate individual 
compliance controls to streamline
the procurement process.

Let’s begin by taking a quick look at the 
AWS Marketplace Vendor Insights page.

This page summarizes the benefits 
of Vendor Insights to both enterprise

customers and software vendors and 
answers frequently asked questions.

Let’s discover products with 
Vendor Insights profiles.

These results include only SaaS products 
with Vendor Insights security profiles.

We can filter further to see only 
those with product certificates.

These products all have SOC 2 
Type 2 and ISO 27001 certificates.
Let’s view a product.

The product overview now includes 
Vendor Insights information.

This link takes us to the product’s Vendor 
Insights profile on AWS Marketplace.

The profile includes a high-level 
overview and shows the certifications

the vendor has received 
and their expiration dates.

Let’s look at the Security 
and compliance tab.

To access to this vendor’s data, 
we’ll need to request access.
Let’s complete the form.
Before we continue, let’s review the next steps.

The seller will contact us directly about
completing a non-disclosure agreement (NDA).

The seller will notify AWS Marketplace
 when our NDA is completed,

and we will then be granted 
access to insight data.

For our purposes, let’s view a 
vendor profile to which we’ve
already been granted access.
Let’s view the product.

In the overview, we can find public 
documentation the vendor supplied,
including a link to a security feed.

The link opens a new tab where we can 
browse the vendor’s security bulletins.
Let’s go back.

This vendor also provided a link to 
its service availability status, which,

in this case, points to an 
AWS Health Dashboard.

Let’s return to the seller’s Vendor 
Insights page and view the Security
and compliance dashboard.

Vendor Insights gathers evidence-
based information about 140
industry-standard security controls.

The page provides details
 for each control category.

The summary reveals how many of 
the vendor’s controls are validated

with evidence or based on self-
reported evidence, and whether
any controls are non-compliant.

Let’s take a closer look at 
the data security category.

First, we’ll drill into the 
data encryption controls.

Control compliance is 
determined by three sources:

Workloads on AWS are validated by 
AWS Config and AWS Audit Manager.

Please note that these are production 
workloads and they are updated bi-weekly.

Compliance or non-compliance is also 
evaluated against industry-standard
audit reports as the second source.

And finally, vendors self-assess their 
own compliance as the third source.
Let’s review the first control.

Here we find more information on the
 evidence provided and control status.
Let’s return to the main product page.

This time we’ll look at a non-compliant 
control in the data security category.

We see the vendor self-reported 
that customer data is transmitted
to countries outside the origin country.
Let’s view the control for more information.

The vendor has supplied an annotation 
explaining why its procedures are non-compliant.

Access to this level of information 
improves procurement speed and
trust when evaluating third-party products.
You’ve just seen how you can

simplify SaaS risk assessment with 
AWS Marketplace Vendor Insights.

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it's your turn to try.
